text: Working in public health,
for me is working in what I like.

I like the science,
I like public health.

I always thank the opportunity.
Many people, when they do this,

they say that "we do
what the governments don't do"
and I don't feel like that.

I thank the opportunity to cooperate
with the government because I think

that public health is a
responsibility of the state.

As a citizen, I like to
contribute if I can,

but I don't want to be
a public employee.

So having the opportunity,
having a window open

to help in public health
is something I thank a lot
because I think it's a problem of all.
So for the foundation,
we worked and we had to learn.

I am a businesswoman,
as you've said.

So, to work in a foundation was
completely new. We had to start again.

The question was,
"how can we help?
What can we do?
We want change."

My father had started working
on Chagas disease.
We wanted
a wider vision.

So Chagas disease is
considered by the WHO

as one of the 20 "Neglected
Tropical Diseases" (NTDs).
So we said, "OK, we will work

on all the neglected tropical diseases
and we'll try to improve access

to health for the people
affected by these diseases.
